This condition is characterised by urinary calculi located in the ureter, and may lead to renal colic. This condition may present with haematuria, dysuria, or pain in the flank, lower abdomen, groin, thighs, or genitalia. Confirmation is by abdominal radiography to determine the presence and location of calculi.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: A condition of the urinary system, caused by dehydration, decreased urine volume or fluid flow rates, or increased excretion of minerals such as calcium, oxalate, magnesium, cystine, and phosphate. This condition is characterised by urinary calculi located in the lower urinary tract (urinary bladder and urethra). This condition may also present with haematuria, dysuria, or pain in the flank, lower abdomen, or groin. Confirmation is by abdominal radiography to determine the presence and location of calculi.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: A condition caused by dehydration, decreased urine volume or fluid flow rates, or increased excretion of minerals such as calcium, oxalate, magnesium, cystine, and phosphate. This condition is characterised by urinary calculi located in the bladder. This condition may also present with haematuria, dysuria, or pain in the flank, lower abdomen, or groin. Confirmation is by abdominal radiography, to determine the presence and location of calculi.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: A condition of the urinary system, caused by dehydration, decreased urine volume or fluid flow rates, or increased excretion of minerals such as calcium, oxalate, magnesium, cystine, and phosphate. This condition is characterised by the presence of calculi originating in the urinary system or are which are located within the urinary system. Confirmation is by abdominal radiography, or intravenous pyelography.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: Diseases where there are developmental anatomical or pathological changes in the renal substance not occurring in a familial distribution and not known to have a mono-genetic cause.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: Multiple cysts in both kidneys increasing in number and size from adolescence, associated with development of hypertension and chronic renal failure. Autosomal dominant familial pattern is usual and due to mutations on Chromosomes 16 and 4. Non-renal manifestations can include cysts in the liver and less commonly pancreas,. Cerebral arterial aneurysms with subarachnoid haemorrhage, and other non-renal vascular abnormalities can also occur.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Category: - - - Cystic or dysplastic kidney disease, unspecified
Defination: Any disease of the kidney, caused by determinants arising during the antenatal period or after birth. These diseases are characterised by pathological changes to one or both kidneys, and may manifest in other anatomical tissues.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Category: - - Certain specified disorders of kidney or ureter
Defination: Any disorder characterised by pathological changes to the kidney or ureter.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: A condition caused by obstruction, stricture, or stenosis of the ureter, which may be due to prostatic hypertrophy, carcinoma, retroperitoneal or pelvic neoplasms, calculi, or a congenital anomaly. This condition is characterised by distention of the ureter with urine.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: Conditions characterised by failure of the kidney to excrete acids, or to lose bicarbonate into the urine, which causes the blood to become too acidic. Characteristically hyperchloremic acidosis (low anion gap metabolic acidosis) . Has several forms and many causes.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
Defination: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a condition in which the kidney tubules respond poorly to pituitary secreted anti-diuretic hormone, resulting in a failure to concentrate the urine, and water loss. Polyuria with dilute urine and polydypsia (excessive thirst) are present. It can be congenital or acquired with many causes. The congenital forms may be attributed to vasopressin receptor or aquaporin -2 defects. They are characterised by polyuria with polydipsia, recurrent bouts of fever, constipation, and acute hypernatraemic dehydration after birth that may cause neurological sequelae.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the bladder, caused by infection, reaction to pharmacological agents, exposure to radiation therapy, or potential irritants. This condition is characterised by inflammation of the urinary bladder, dysuria, pollakiuria, fever, or flank pain.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: Any disorder characterised by pathological changes to the urinary bladder.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the bladder, caused by congenital or acquired obstruction to the bladder outlet, a bladder dysfunction following a nerve injury, or a prior bladder surgery. This condition is characterised by balloon-like protrusions on the bladder lining, leading to an area of weakness in the bladder wall. This condition may be asymptomatic, or present with recurrent bladder infections, difficulty urinating, or abdominal fullness. Confirmation is by contrast radiography or cystoscopy.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the urethra, caused by non-infectious factors such as trauma, allergies, anatomical malformations, or scarring and adhesions following a medical intervention. This condition is characterised by inflammation of the urethra, chronic recurrent urinary tract infections without bacterial growth, and pyuria.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the urethra, caused by an obstruction to the periurethral glands that is commonly the result of frequent infection. This condition is characterised by a focal accumulation of purulent material within or on the urethral tissue.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: Stenosis of the urethra accompanied by fibrosis and scarring of the spongiosal body

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: Any condition caused by trauma, medical intervention, infection, cancer, or congenital factors. This condition is characterised by the formation of an abnormal passage between any two locations within the genitourinary tract.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the urethra, caused by surgery, infection, trauma, or congenital factors. This condition is characterised by the formation of an abnormal passage between the urethra and adjacent organs or surfaces.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: Any condition characterised by the formation of an abnormal passage between the genital tract and another organ, or between a genital organ and an adjacent organ or surface.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the bladder and vagina, caused by and subsequent to childbirth, trauma, hysterectomy, medical intervention, infections, bladder calculi, endometriosis, cone biopsy, or congenital factors. This condition is characterised by the formation of an abnormal passage between the urinary bladder and the vagina, leading to the continuous involuntary discharge of urine into the vagina.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: This refers to the abnormal connection or passageway between the female urethra and the vagina without further specification.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition of the rectum and vagina, caused by childbirth, trauma, Crohn's disease, medical intervention, or infection. This condition is characterised by the formation of an abnormal passage between the rectum and the vagina, not otherwise specified.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Category: - - - - Other specified fistula of the genitourinary tract

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A disease of the urethra, caused by an obstruction to the periurethral glands due to subsequent to frequent infection, or congenitally. This disease is characterised by a localised protrusion of the urethra into the anterior vaginal wall, consisting mostly of fibrous tissue. This disease may also present with urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. Confirmation is by imaging to determine the extent and location of the diverticulum.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Defination: A condition characterised by small, focal, benign, pink or red polypoid masses of the distal urethral mucosa, which may become painful, bloody, and deep red in colour. This condition may be associated with urogenital atrophy due to estrogen deficiency, and may be aggravated by chronic irritation of urethral mucosa exposure. This condition typically affects postmenopausal women.

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system
Category: - - - Urinary tract infection, site not specified

BlockL1: - Diseases of the urinary system
BlockL2: - - Certain specified diseases of urinary system

BlockL1: - Other conditions of the genitourinary system
Defination: The descent of one or more of the anterior vaginal wall, posterior vaginal wall, the uterus (cervix), or the apex of the vagina (vaginal vault) or cuff scar after hysterectomy.

BlockL1: - Other conditions of the genitourinary system
- Other conditions of the genitourinary system
- Other conditions of the genitourinary system
Defination: A condition caused by procedures or other interventions for non-medical purposes. This condition is characterised by the partial or total removal of the external female genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs.

BlockL1: - Postprocedural disorders of genitourinary system
Defination: A condition caused by or subsequent to any vaginal surgery or intervention. This condition is characterised by fibrous bands of scar tissue between the intravaginal tissues (intravaginal adhesions). This condition may also present with pelvic pain and dyspareunia.

BlockL1: - Postprocedural disorders of genitourinary system
BlockL2: - - Prolapse of vaginal vault after hysterectomy
Category: - - Prolapse of vaginal vault after hysterectomy
Defination: A condition of the vagina, caused by or subsequent to hysterectomy. This condition is characterised by descensus of the vaginal vault that may also lead to weakening of the vaginal walls.

BlockL1: - Postprocedural disorders of genitourinary system
Defination: Urethral stricture caused by catheterization, transurethral manipulations (e.g. transurethral resections), urethral instillations, or irradiation exposure

BlockL1: - Postprocedural disorders of genitourinary system
Defination: A condition caused by or subsequent to any pelvic intervention leading to damage and inflammation of the peritoneum. This condition is characterised by fibrous bands of scar tissue and abnormal connection between pelvic organs or tissues. This condition may also present with pelvic pain or bowel obstruction.

Category: - Other specified diseases of the genitourinary system

BlockL1: - Sexual dysfunctions
synonymous DSM - 5: Male Hypoactive Sexual Desire Disorder, Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder
Defination: Hypoactive Sexual Desire Dysfunction is characterised by absence or marked reduction in desire or motivation to engage in sexual activity as manifested by any of the following: 1) reduced or absent spontaneous desire (sexual thoughts or fantasies); 2) reduced or absent responsive desire to erotic cues and stimulation; or 3) inability to sustain desire or interest in sexual activity once initiated. The pattern of diminished or absent spontaneous or responsive desire or inability to sustain desire or interest in sexual activity has occurred episodically or persistently over a period at least several months, and is associated with clinically significant distress.

BlockL1: - Sexual dysfunctions
Defination: Sexual arousal dysfunctions include difficulties with the physiological or the subjective aspects of sexual arousal.

BlockL1: - Sexual dysfunctions
- Sexual dysfunctions
Defination: Orgasmic dysfunctions refer to difficulties related to the subjective experience of orgasm.

BlockL1: - Sexual dysfunctions
Defination: The onset of anorgasmia has followed a period of time during which the person did not experience it and the desired response is currently absent or diminished in all circumstances, including masturbation.

BlockL1: - Sexual dysfunctions
Defination: Ejaculatory dysfunctions refer to difficulties with ejaculation in men, including ejaculatory latencies that are experienced as too short (Male early ejaculation) or too long (Male delayed ejaculation).

BlockL1: - Sexual dysfunctions
- Gender incongruence
Defination: Sexual Dysfunctions are syndromes that comprise the various ways in which adult people may have difficulty experiencing personally satisfying, non-coercive sexual activities. Sexual response is a complex interaction of psychological, interpersonal, social, cultural and physiological processes and one or more of these factors may affect any stage of the sexual response. In order to be considered a sexual dysfunction, the dysfunction must: 1) occur frequently, although it may be absent on some occasions; 2) have been present for at least several months; and 3) be associated with clinically significant distress.

BlockL1: - Sexual pain disorders
Defination: Sexual pain-penetration disorder is characterised by at least one of the following: 1) marked and persistent or recurrent difficulties with penetration, including due to involuntary tightening or tautness of the pelvic floor muscles during attempted penetration; 2) marked and persistent or recurrent vulvovaginal or pelvic pain during penetration; 3) marked and persistent or recurrent fear or anxiety about vulvovaginal or pelvic pain in anticipation of, during, or as a result of penetration. The symptoms are recurrent during sexual interactions involving or potentially involving penetration, despite adequate sexual desire and stimulation, are not entirely attributable to a medical condition that adversely affects the pelvic area and results in genital and/or penetrative pain or to a mental disorder, are not entirely attributable to insufficient vaginal lubrication or post-menopausal/ age-related changes, and are associated with clinically significant distress.

BlockL1: - Other specified conditions related to sexual health
Category: - Other specified conditions related to sexual health

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
- Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: A condition caused by immunological factors, abnormal ovum or uterine body, maternal disease or infection, or cervical incompetence. This condition is characterised by non-induced embryonic or fetal death or passage of products of conception prior to 22 weeks gestation or weighing less than 500 grams.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: Intentional loss of an intrauterine pregnancy due to medical or surgical means.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: Ongoing pregnancy after medical or surgical interventions which fail to terminate the pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: Any condition characterised by implantation of the embryo outside the endometrium and endometrial cavity during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: A condition characterised by implantation of the embryo within the peritoneal cavity during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: A condition characterised by implantation of the embryo within the fallopian tube (ampullary, isthmus, interstitium) during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: A condition characterised by implantation of the embryo within the ovary during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: Any condition characterised by implantation of the embryo outside the endometrium and endometrial cavity during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Defination: A condition caused by the over-production of cells arising into the placenta during pregnancy. This condition is characterised by a pregnancy with abnormal placental growth in which the chorionic villi become hydropic, trophoblast proliferation and invasion of the uterine tissue within 10-16 weeks after conception, and a placental mass.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
synonymous: Early fetal death with retention of dead fetus
Defination: A condition caused by genetic abnormality, abnormal cell division, or poor quality ovum or sperm. This condition is characterised by a failed pregnancy, immature fetal or embryonic death that is not expelled from the uterus for at least 8 weeks, and diminished uterine size. This condition may also present with maternal infection, blood clotting, fetal calcification, and resorption of conception products. Confirmation is by imaging.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Category: - - Complications following abortion, ectopic or molar pregnancy
Defination: Any complication affecting pregnant females, caused by or subsequent to abortion, ectopic, and molar pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Category: - - - Genital tract or pelvic infection following abortion, ectopic or molar pregnancy

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Category: - - - Embolism following abortion, ectopic or molar pregnancy

BlockL1: - Abortive outcome of pregnancy
Category: - - - Other specified complications following abortion, ectopic or molar pregnancy

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Defination: A condition affecting pregnant females over 20 weeks gestation. This condition is characterised by systolic blood pressure greater than 140mmHg and diastolic greater or equal to 90mmHg on two occasions 4 hours apart in the presence of either proteinuria or other new onset maternal organ dysfunction characterised by one thrombocytopenia, elevated serum creatinine or liver transaminases, or neurological conditions or fetal growth restriction in a female diagnosed with pre-existing hypertension.

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Category: - - Gestational oedema or proteinuria without hypertension
synonymous: Pregnancy-induced oedema and proteinuria without hypertension
Defination: A condition affecting pregnant females, characterised by excessive systemic fluid build-up and serum proteins in the urine, without an abnormally elevated blood pressure induced by pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Defination: A condition affecting pregnant females, characterised by systolic blood pressure greater than 140mmHg and/or a diastolic blood pressure greater or equal to 90mmHg on two occasions, 4 hours or more apart. Can be newly diagnosed after 20 weeks gestation or before 1 week postpartum. Confirmation is by measurement of blood pressure, liver and kidney functions test, and urine test.

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Defination: This condition is characterised by systolic blood pressure greater than 140mmHg and or diastolic greater or equal to 90mmHg on two occasions 4 hours or more apart in the presence of either proteinuria or other new onset maternal organ dysfunction characterised by one thrombocytopenia, elevated serum creatinine or liver transaminases, or neurological conditions or fetal growth restriction.

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Defination: This condition is characterised by systolic blood pressure greater than 140mmHg and or diastolic greater or equal to 90mmHg on two occasions 4 hours or more apart in the presence of either proteinuria or other new onset maternal organ dysfunction characterised by one thrombocytopenia, elevated serum creatinine or liver transaminases, or neurological conditions or fetal growth restriction.

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Defination: severe preeclampsia associated with haemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, or low platelets

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Defination: Any condition affecting pregnant females, characterised by seizure or convulsions newly arising in pregnancy. The condition is often associated with pregnancy-induced hypertension, convulsions, seizure, anxiety, epigastric pain, severe headache, blurred vision, proteinuria, and oedema that may occur during pregnancy, labour, or the puerperium.

BlockL1: - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium
Category: - - Oedema, proteinuria, or hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium, unspecified
Defination: Any disorder affecting pregnant females, characterised by excessive systemic fluid build-up, excess serum proteins in the urine, and abnormally elevated blood pressure during pregnancy, childbirth, or the puerperium.

BlockL1: - Obstetric haemorrhage
- Obstetric haemorrhage
synonymous: Haemorrhage specified as due to threatened abortion
Defination: A bloody vaginal discharge of bleeding appears through a closed cervical os during the first half of pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Obstetric haemorrhage
- Obstetric haemorrhage
- Obstetric haemorrhage
- Obstetric haemorrhage
Defination: A condition characterised by excessive loss of blood within the first 24 hours after the completion of the third stage of labour for a vaginal delivery (more than 500 millilitres), or after a caesarean section (more than 1000 millilitres). This condition is caused by uterine atony, trauma, retained placenta, or coagulopathy.

BlockL1: - Obstetric haemorrhage
Defination: A condition characterised by excessive loss of blood between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery. This condition is caused by uterine atony, trauma, retained placenta, or coagulopathy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
- Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
- Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Varicose veins of lower extremity in pregnancy

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
- Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
- Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
- Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: A condition affecting females during pregnancy, caused by an increase in intra-abdominal pressure and hormonal changes during pregnancy. This condition is characterised by enlarged and varicosed haemorrhoidal veins in the anus and lower rectum. This condition may also present with itching, burning, painful swellings at the anus, dyschezia or rectal bleeding with bowel movements. Confirmation is by digital or visual examination with an anoscope, proctoscope, or sigmoidoscope of the anal canal and rectum to determine the presence of haemorrhoids.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - Infections of genitourinary tract in pregnancy

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: A condition caused by dysfunctional maternal insulin receptors. This condition is characterised by glucose intolerance with onset or first recognition during pregnancy, with at least one of the following criteria met: fasting plasma glucose greater than or equal to 7.0 millimoles per litre (126 mg/ dL); 2-hour plasma glucose greater than or equal to 11.1 millimoles per litre (200 mg/dL) following a 75 gram oral glucose load; random plasma glucose greater than or equal to 11.1 millimoles per litre (200 mg/ dL). Confirmation is by an oral glucose tolerance test.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Pre-existing type 1 diabetes mellitus in pregnancy

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Pre-existing type 2 diabetes mellitus in pregnancy

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: Diabetes mellitus arising or diagnosed in pregnancy (per WHO criteria or other national criteria)-Gestational diabetes. Gestational diabetes mellitus is defined as any degree of glucose intolerance with onset or first recognition during pregnancy. The definition applies regardless of whether insulin or only diet modification is used for treatment or whether the condition persists after pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: A condition caused by ingestion of a diet in which the nutrients are lacking or are in excess.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - Maternal care for other conditions predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: Any reason for encounter to assess (or care for) a mother for other conditions predominantly related to pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: A group of skin disorders which are specific to pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: Any reason for encounter to assess (or care for) a mother for excessive weight gain during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: Any reason for encounter to assess (or care for) a mother for low weight gain during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Defination: Any reason for encounter to assess a mother for low blood pressure during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Subluxation of symphysis pubis in pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
Defination: Any reason for encounter to assess (or care for) a mother for subluxation of pubis symphysis during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
- Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Spinal or epidural anaesthesia-induced headache during pregnancy
Defination: A condition affecting females during pregnancy, caused by the administration of spinal and epidural anaesthesia. This condition is characterised by cephalgia during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Failed or difficult intubation during pregnancy
Defination: A condition affecting females during pregnancy, caused by physiological, pathophysiological, or psychological factors that aggravate the tissues necessary to secure the tube. This condition is characterised by a difficulty or inability to insert a tube into an external or internal orifice of the body during pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Certain specified maternal disorders predominantly related to pregnancy
Category: - - - Complications of anaesthesia during pregnancy, unspecified

BlockL1: - Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
Category: - - Maternal care related to multiple gestation

BlockL1: - Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
- Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
- Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
- Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
Defination: Excessive amniotic fluid normally diagnosed on ultrasound either subjectively using either single deepest vertical pocket of greater or equal to 8cm and /or amniotic fluid index greater or equal to 24cm

BlockL1: - Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
Category: - - Maternal care related to certain specified disorders of amniotic fluid or membranes

BlockL1: - Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
- Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
Category: - - Maternal care related to premature rupture of membranes
Defination: Spontaneous rupture of fetal membranes before the onset of labour.

BlockL1: - Maternal care related to the fetus, amniotic cavity or possible delivery problems
- Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: A condition characterised by the onset of labour and delivery before 37 completed weeks. Assign an additional extension code, if desired, for Duration of pregnancy.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: A condition characterised by a failed attempt to stimulate contractions before the spontaneous onset of labour. This condition may occur with or without ruptured membranes.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: Any condition affecting pregnant females, characterised by an anomaly or dysfunction to the tissues or processes associated with the natural progression of labour. These conditions may lead to further complications during labour and childbirth.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: A condition affecting pregnant females that is idiopathic. This condition is characterised by rapid labour and the lack of time for standard obstetric preparations or procedures leading to the delivery of the newborn. This condition leads to vaginal bleeding, frequent strong contractions, feelings of defecation, crowning of the fetus head at the vaginal introitus, or bulging of the amniotic sac.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: Any condition characterised by a longer than average parturition between the initiation of regular, rhythmic, and painful contractions and cervical dilation, to the delivery of the placenta.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: The first stage of labour where cervical dilatation progresses less than 1 centimetre per hour for a minimum of 4 hours. Protracted descent is less than 1 centimetre per hour for nulliparas and less than 2 centimetre per hour for multiparas.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: The fetus has not been delivered after the cervix has become fully dilated within 2 hours for a primipara, or 1 hour for a multipara. Presence of regional anaesthesia will add 1 hour.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Obstructed labour due to malposition or malpresentation of fetus
Defination: A condition affecting pregnant females, caused by the abnormal position of fetal head or the abnormal presentation of the fetus away from the fetal head in vertex.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Obstructed labour due to maternal pelvic abnormality
Defination: Obstructed labour means that, in spite of strong contractions of the uterus, the fetus cannot descend through the pelvis because there is an insurmountable barrier preventing its descent. Obstruction usually occurs at the pelvic brim, but occasionally it may occur in the cavity or at the outlet of the pelvis. Complications resulting from obstructed labour can be avoided if a woman in obstructed labour is identified early and appropriate action is taken.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Obstructed labour due to other causes
Defination: Any other condition characterised by the inability of the presenting part of the fetus to progress into the birth canal for any reason.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Labour or delivery complicated by fetal distress

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Labour or delivery complicated by umbilical cord complications

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: An injury characterised by a laceration to the maternal perineum during delivery.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: Any injury characterised by maternal trauma. These injuries are caused by or subsequent to the process of (or any intervention related to) pregnancy, or labour and delivery.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - - Rupture of uterus before onset of labour
Defination: An injury characterised by rupture of the myometrial wall of the uterus before the onset of labour. This injury is caused by pregnancy. This injury presents with abdominal pain, haemorrhage, or hypovolemic shock in the mother, or late decelerations, reduced variability, tachycardia, or bradycardia in the fetus.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
synonymous: Rupture of uterus not stated as occurring before onset of labour
Defination: An injury characterised by rupture of the myometrial wall of the uterus during labour. This injury is caused by or subsequent to the process of (or any intervention related to) pregnancy, or labour and delivery. This injury presents with abdominal pain, haemorrhage, or hypovolemic shock in the mother, or late decelerations, reduced variability, tachycardia, or bradycardia in the fetus.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: An injury characterised by uterine inversion and prolapse through the dilated cervix that occurs after the delivery of a neonate. This condition is caused by or subsequent to labour and delivery, commonly as a result of excessive fundal pressure or cord traction. This condition presents with postpartum haemorrhage.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - - Obstetric damage to pelvic joints or ligaments
Defination: An injury characterised by damage to the pelvic joints and ligaments. This injury is caused by or subsequent to the process of (or any intervention related to) pregnancy, or labour and delivery.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: An injury characterised by a collection of extravasated blood trapped in the pelvic tissues. This injury is caused by or subsequent to the process of (or any intervention related to) pregnancy, or labour and delivery. This condition may also present with bruising or blood clots in the pelvic area.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Retained placenta or membranes, without haemorrhage
Defination: A condition characterised by a placenta or membranes that have not been expelled from the uterus during the third stage of labour and up to 30 minutes following delivery, and without haemorrhage. This condition is caused by uterine atony, a trapped placenta, or a placenta accreta. This condition may lead to primary postpartum haemorrhage or infection.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Defination: A condition characterised by a placenta that has not been expelled from the uterus during the third stage of labour and up to 30 minutes following delivery, and without haemorrhage. This condition is caused by uterine atony, a trapped placenta, or a placenta accreta. This condition may lead to primary postpartum haemorrhage or infection.

BlockL1: - Complications of labour or delivery
Category: - - Other specified complications of labour or delivery

BlockL1: - Delivery
Defination: A condition caused by the development of a fetus to the culmination of the pregnancy period. This condition is characterised by spontaneous parturition of a neonate from the uterus.

BlockL1: - Delivery
Category: - - Single delivery by forceps or vacuum extractor
Defination: A condition caused by the development of a fetus to the culmination of the pregnancy period. This condition is characterised by parturition of a neonate from the uterus using forceps and vacuum extractor to assist the delivery.

BlockL1: - Delivery
Defination: A condition caused by the development of a fetus to the culmination of the pregnancy period. This condition is characterised by parturition of a single neonate from the uterus by caesarean section.

BlockL1: - Delivery
- Delivery
Defination: A condition caused by the development of a fetus to the culmination of the pregnancy period. This condition is characterised by parturition of a neonate in breech position from the uterus using breech extraction interventions or techniques to assist the delivery.

BlockL1: - Delivery
Defination: A condition caused by the development of more than one fetus to the culmination of the pregnancy period. This condition is characterised by parturition of more than one neonate from the uterus either spontaneously, assisted, or by caesarean section.

BlockL1: - Delivery
Defination: A condition caused by the development of more than one fetus to the culmination of the pregnancy period. This condition is characterised by parturition of more than one neonate from the uterus either spontaneously, assisted, or by caesarean section.

BlockL1: - Delivery
- Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
- Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Defination: Any type of infection - bacterial, viral, fungal or protozoal, can cause sepsis and must be coded first. When the site of infection is unknown, select a code for Infection of unspecified site by organism followed by the appropriate code for sepsis.

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
- Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
- Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Defination: A condition characterised by the lodging of a blood clot, a fat globule or a gas bubble (embolus) in the bloodstream, which can cause a blockage associated with the physiological and other changes that occur during the period of time from conception to delivery (pregnancy), during labour and delivery (childbirth) or during the approximately six weeks after delivery during which the uterus returns to the original size (puerperium).

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Defination: A condition characterised by the lodging of a gas bubble (air embolus) in the bloodstream, which can cause a blockage associated with the physiological and other changes that occur during the period of time from conception to delivery (pregnancy), during labour and delivery (childbirth) or during the approximately six weeks after delivery during which the uterus returns to the original size (puerperium).

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Defination: Amniotic fluid embolism is a rare obstetric emergency in which it is postulated that amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter the maternal circulation, causing cardiorespiratory collapse.

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Defination: A condition characterised by the lodging of a blood clot (a specific type of embolus known as a thrombus) in the bloodstream, which can cause a blockage associated with the physiological and other changes that occur during the period of time from conception to delivery (pregnancy), during labour and delivery (childbirth) or during the approximately six weeks after delivery during which the uterus returns to the original size (puerperium).

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Category: - - Infections of breast associated with childbirth

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Category: - - Certain specified disorders of breast or lactation associated with childbirth

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Defination: A condition characterised as the abnormal inversion of a nipple that does not return to normal position even when stimulated that has occurred in association with childbirth.

BlockL1: - Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
- Complications predominantly related to the puerperium
Category: - - - Other or unspecified disorders of breast associated with childbirth

BlockL1: - Certain obstetric conditions, not elsewhere classified
Category: - - Death from sequelae of obstetric causes
Defination: A secondary condition of pregnant females, caused by and subsequent to any complications during pregnancy, childbirth, or puerperium. This condition is characterised by maternal death.

BlockL1: - Certain obstetric conditions, not elsewhere classified
Category: - - - Death from sequelae of direct obstetric cause
Defination: Any condition directly resulting in death due to a pathological condition resulting from any adverse evolution (complication) which may arise associated with the period of time from conception to delivery (pregnancy), during labour and delivery (childbirth) or during the approximately six weeks after delivery during which the uterus returns to the original size (puerperium).

BlockL1: - Certain obstetric conditions, not elsewhere classified
Category: - - - Death from sequelae of indirect obstetric cause
Defination: Any condition resulting in death via an intermediate cause due to a pathological condition resulting from any adverse evolution (complication) which may arise associated with the period of time from conception to delivery (pregnancy), during labour and delivery (childbirth) or during the approximately six weeks after delivery during which the uterus returns to the original size (puerperium).

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal conditions that may be unrelated to present pregnancy
Defination: A group of conditions characterised by findings in the fetus or newborn due to conditions associated with the mother which are unrelated to the present pregnancy.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal complications of pregnancy
Defination: Any other condition characterised by findings in the fetus or newborn due to any condition of the mother due to an adverse evolution (complication) which may arise associated with the time period from conception through childbirth.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by complications of placenta
Defination: A group of conditions characterised by findings in the fetus or newborn due to an adverse evolution (complication) associated with the placenta, umbilical cord, or chorioamniotic membranes.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by complications of umbilical cord

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by other abnormalities of membranes

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - - Fetus or newborn affected by chorioamnionitis
Defination: Chorioamnionitis is an infection of the placental tissues and amniotic fluid. It can lead to bacteraemia in the mother, which is an infection of the blood, and this can cause preterm birth or infection in the newborn. Organisms which are usually responsible for chorioamnionitis include Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Group B streptococcus.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by certain complications of labour or delivery
Defination: A group of conditions characterised by findings in the fetus or newborn due to any other adverse evolution (complication) during labour and delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Fetus or newborn affected by noxious influences transmitted via placenta or breast milk
Defination: A group of conditions characterised by findings in the fetus or newborn due to the transmission of any harmful or poisonous substance to the fetus or newborn via the placenta or in breast milk.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Fetus or newborn affected by maternal factors or by complications of pregnancy, labour or delivery
Category: - - Neonatal dermatoses due to maternal antibodies
Defination: A range of antibody-mediated neonatal skin disorders due to transplacental transfer of maternal antibodies to the fetus. The relevant autoimmune disorder may or may not be apparent in the mother.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Category: - - Disorders of newborn related to slow fetal growth or fetal malnutrition

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Defination: Birth weight below Ð 2 standard deviations of the mean or below the 10th percentile according to local intrauterine growth charts

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Category: - - Disorders of newborn related to short gestation or low birth weight, not elsewhere classified
Defination: Infants whose weight is appropriate for their gestational ages are termed appropriate for gestational age (AGA). Infants that are heavier than expected are large for gestational age (LGA). Conversely, those smaller than expected are considered small for gestational age (SGA).

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Category: - - - Extremely low birth weight of newborn
Defination: Newborn birth weight 999 g. or less. Infants have increased morbidity including neurosensory disability, cerebral palsy, retinopathy of prematurity, deafness, pulmonary immaturity, chronic lung disease and subnormal cognitive function.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Category: - - - Very low birth weight of newborn
Defination: A paediatric condition in which the infant is born weighing between 1000 g and 1499

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Defination: A paediatric condition in which the infant is born weighing between 1500 g and 2499 g

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Defination: Preterm: <37 weeks or 259 days gestation.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Category: - - Disorders of newborn related to long gestation or high birth weight
Defination: Usually implies gestation > 290 or 294 days (42 weeks); high birthweight = >4000g.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Defination: A birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for gestational age or birth weight of 4000 g or to 4499 g at term regardless of period of gestation.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Defination: A condition of the newborn characterised by a gestational period that reached or exceeded 42 completed weeks (294 days or more) of gestation.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Disorders of newborn related to length of gestation or fetal growth
Defination: Post-term infant with signs of dysmaturity including dry peeling wrinkled skin, yellow staining of the skin, long stained fingernails, abundant scalp hair, thin growth retarded body with long thin limbs and hyperalert behaviours.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - Birth injury to central nervous system
Defination: A condition characterised by the presence of damage to the central nervous system due to physical pressure or injury during delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Subdural haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Haemorrhage into the subdural space (between the dura and the arachnoid) resulting from traumatic tearing of the bridging veins and venous sinuses due to rotational movement of the brain secondary to a traumatic delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Cerebral haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Cerebral haemorrhage due to birth injury refers to haemorrhage occurring into the cerebral parenchyma as a result of birth trauma, and is commonly accompanied by extracerebral contusion and/or bleeding haemorrhage in the scalp. May have associated skull fracture(s).

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Cerebellar haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Haemorrhage into the cerebellum, hemispheres or vermis, due to trauma. Occipitaloseodiastasis with breech delivery is the most common cause of this injury.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Intraventricular haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Traumatic haemorrhage into the intraventricular space as the dominant lesion, usually in a term infant, a result of birth trauma. Usually seen in conjunction with other intracranial bleeding (parenchymal, subdural, subarachnoid) and can be seen in the term or preterm infant.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Subarachnoid haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Haemorrhage within the subarachnoid space (the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia matter) due to either leakage from the leptomeningeal plexus or rupture of bridging veins within the subarachnoid space.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Tentorial tear due to birth injury
Defination: Lacerations of tentorium cerebelli due to birth trauma, usually resulting in infratentorial haemorrhages; lesser degrees of tentorial injury most commonly associated with subdural bleeds.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Cerebellar contusion due to birth injury
Defination: A bruise of the brain tissue. There is a punctuate haemorrhage which occurs in the long gyri.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Cerebral contusion due to birth injury
Defination: A bruise of the brain tissue. Focal region of necrosis and haemorrhage, usually involving the cerebral cortex and subcortical white matter

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - - Extradural or epidural haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Haemorrhage in the plane between the skull bone and the periosteum on the inner surface of the skull from injury to the middle meningeal artery from birth trauma

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: Ocular injuries due to birth trauma include lid lacerations, hyphema, rupture of Descemet's membrane of cornea, vitreous haemorrhage, corneal oedema, abrasions and lacerations, orbital haemorrhage and fractures, and intraocular haemorrhages.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: A condition characterised by the presence of damage to the scalp due to physical pressure or injury during delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: Cephalhaematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood caused by rupture of vessels beneath the periosteum and does not extend across the suture lines.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - Subgaleal epicranial subaponeurotic haemorrhage due to birth injury
Defination: Subgaleal haemorrhage is a collection of blood in the space between the epicranial aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum of the skull.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - Birth injury to skin or soft tissues
Defination: Superficial injury including abrasions, lacerations and ecchymoses sustained during birth to sites other than scalp face and external genitalia

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - Birth injury to peripheral nervous system
Defination: A condition characterised by the presence of damage to the nerves and ganglia outside of the brain and spinal cord due to physical pressure or injury during delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: Facial palsy involving both upper and lower halves of the face caused by traumatic compression of the facial nerve as it exits the stylomastoid foramen, or as it passes over the ramus of the mandible.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: Erb paralysis is one of the most common brachial plexus birth palsy. The injury occurs in the upper brachial plexus nerves and affects the upper arm.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: A condition characterised by the presence of damage to the skeleton due to physical pressure or injury during delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - Fracture of skull due to birth injury
Defination: Linear or depressed fractures of skull bones resulting from injury during birth, including those related to forceps and vacuum assisted delivery

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Category: - - - Fracture of clavicle due to birth injury
Defination: This is a greenstick fracture of the clavicle that may occur during the birthing process.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Birth injury
Defination: A group of conditions characterised by the presence of damage of organs of a newly delivered child due to physical pressure or injury during delivery.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Category: - - Other bacterial infections of the fetus or newborn

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Defination: A disease affecting infants, caused by an infection with the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis in utero. Transmission is by vertical transmission.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Category: - - Viral infection in the fetus or newborn
Defination: Any condition affecting fetuses or newborns, caused by an infection with a virus.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Category: - - Fungal infection of fetus or newborn
Defination: Any condition affecting fetuses or newborns, caused by an infection with a fungal agent.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Category: - - Neonatal infections of certain specified sites

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Defination: This refers to inflammation of the conjunctiva (the outermost layer of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids) and the inflammation of the nasolacrimal sac, frequently caused by nasolacrimal duct obstruction or infection.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Defination: A disease of the umbilical cord affecting newborns, commonly caused by an infection with a bacterial source. This disease is characterised by purulent or foul-smelling discharge from the umbilicus or umbilical stump, periumbilical erythema, oedema, or tenderness. This disease may also present with fever, hypothermia, jaundice, tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnoea, respiratory distress, apnoea, or abdominal distention with absent bowel sounds. Transmission is by vertical transmission or iatrogenic transmission. Confirmation is by identification of the infectious agent.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Infections of the fetus or newborn
Defination: A condition of the urinary tract affecting neonates, commonly caused by an infection with a bacterial source. This condition is characterised by fever, pyuria, jaundice, poor appetite, diarrhoea, blood tinged stool, vomiting, or abdominal distention. This condition may also be asymptomatic. Transmission is by vertical transmission. Confirmation is by identification of the infectious agent in a urine sample.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: fetal blood loss is a loss of blood from the fetal circulation during pregnancy, labour, or delivery. Due to the small volume of fetal blood that is present, even a small loss can lead to anaemia or fetal death.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: A condition characterised by bleeding from the umbilical cord stump of a newborn.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Category: - - Haemolytic disease of fetus or newborn
Defination: A paediatric alloimmune condition characterised by the break-down of red blood cells by IgG antibodies which are transmitted from mother to child via the placenta.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Category: - - Hydrops fetalis due to haemolytic disease
Defination: A fetal condition characterised by an accumulation of fluid or oedema in at least two fetal compartments, including subcutaneous compartments, the pleura, the pericardium, or the abdomen, due to the antibody-mediated break-down of fetal red blood cells.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: Kernicterus is a pathologic diagnosis of the neonate that is characterised by yellow staining of the basal ganglia following elevated bilirubin concentrations in the blood and/or a breech in the blood brain barrier more common in the premature infant or the sick term neonate. It is characterised later in infancy and childhood by hearing deficits, choreoathetosis, and varying degrees of cognitive deficit.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: A condition characterised as an increased level of bilirubin above 85 umol/l (5 mg/dL) which manifests as yellowing of the eyes, skin, and other tissues of a newborn due to excessive break-down of red blood cells for any other reason not classified elsewhere.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Category: - - Disseminated intravascular coagulation of fetus or newborn
Defination: Neonatal purpura fulminans is a potentially lethal disorder characterised by progressive haemorrhagic necrosis of the skin associated with cutaneous vascular thrombosis. It is usually due to a genetically transmitted thrombophilic disorder: most commonly homozygous deficiency of protein C or, less frequently, protein S.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: A rare paediatric condition characterised by a temporary relative decrease in the number of platelets in the blood associated with either increased destruction or decreased production of platelets in a newborn.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: Polycythaemia of the neonate represents an excessive quality of circulating red blood cells due to excessive marrow production and haematocrits that exceed ~60%.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: A paediatric condition characterised by a decrease in number of red blood cells (RBCs) or less than the normal quantity of haemoglobin in the blood of a newborn associated with the child being born prior to completing 37 weeks of gestation.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Haemorrhagic or haematological disorders of fetus or newborn
Defination: There are 3 forms of vitamin KÐdeficiency bleeding (VKDB) of the newborn. Early VKDB (haemorrhagic disease of the newborn) that occurs at 1-14 days of age. The most common sites of bleeding are the gastrointestinal tract, mucosal and cutaneous tissue, the umbilical stump, and the post-circumcision site. Late VKDB most commonly occurs at 2-12 weeks of age, although cases can occur up to 6 months. The most common site of bleeding is intracranial, although cutaneous and gastrointestinal bleeding may be initial manifestation. The third form of VKDB occurs at birth or shortly thereafter. It is secondary to maternal intake of medications (warfarin, phenobarbital, phenytoin) that cross the placenta.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A paediatric condition characterised by insufficient blood flow to the brain of a newborn to meet metabolic demand.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A paediatric condition characterised by the development of cysts around the brain ventricles in a newborn.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A paediatric condition characterised by the death of small areas of brain tissue creating "holes" in the brain of a newborn.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Encephalopathy is disorder of the brain. It may be the result of interference in the development of the brain, an infection or other condition in the neonate.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy (HIE) is when a newbornÕs brain fails to receive a sufficient amount of oxygen or blood before and during birth that may lead to brain damage or death.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A paediatric condition characterised by rapid and repeated muscle contraction and relaxation, resulting in an uncontrolled shaking of the body of a newborn.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Neurological disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - Disorders of muscle tone of newborn
Defination: A group of paediatric conditions characterised by abnormal muscle tone in a newborn.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Intrauterine hypoxia occurs when the fetus is deprived of an adequate supply of oxygen. This may occur with prolapse or occlusion of the umbilical cord, placental infarction and maternal smoking. This can lead to damage of the central nervous system and neonatal encephalopathy, which increases the risk of mortality.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A condition characterised by a by developmental insufficiency of surfactant associated proteins or surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is an acute illness, usually of preterm infants, due to pulmonary surfactant deficiency, developing within 4-6 hours of birth, and is characterised by respiratory distress (tachypnoea, intercostal and sternal retractions, expiratory grunt, and cyanosis with abnormal chest radiograph showing diffuse reticulogranular densities and air bronchograms, evidence of reduced lung compliance and functional residual capacity, evidence of abnormal gas exchange (hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, cyanosis) of sufficient severity to require oxygen and/or continuous or intermittent positive pressure ventilatory support for more than 24 hours.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Transient tachypnoea of newborn is usually a benign self-limiting illness of term and near-term infants demonstrating increased respiratory rate and requiring supplementary oxygen after birth.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A disease of the trachea in neonates, caused by an infection with a bacterial, viral, or fungal source. This disease is characterised by stridor, or increased respiratory effort. Transmission is commonly by inhalation of the infectious agent. Confirmation is by direct laryngoscopy.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Aspiration of meconium, blood, amniotic fluids and gastric contents in a neonate resulting in clinical symptoms from airway obstruction (atelectasis, air trapping and air leaks), parenchymal injury (pneumonitis), right-to-left shunting, and ventilation-perfusion mismatch.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Meconium Aspiration Syndrome (MAS) is defined as respiratory distress in an infant born through meconium-stained amniotic fluid with roentgenographic findings consistent with MAS and whose symptoms could not be otherwise explained.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Neonatal aspiration of milk or regurgitated food
Defination: Clinical symptoms of Neonatal aspiration syndrome due to aspiration of acidic gastric contest and/or milk

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - Pulmonary air leak or related conditions originating in the perinatal period
Defination: Clinical syndrome due to free air from rupture of overdistended alveoli tracking into pulmonary interstitium, mediastinum, pleural cavity or subcutaneous tissues.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Interstitial emphysema originating in the perinatal period
Defination: Escape of air into the interstitium, lymphatics and venous circulation of the lungs resulting from rupture of small airways associated with a characteristic cystic appearance on chest X-ray, almost exclusively seen in preterm infants receiving mechanical ventilation

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Pneumothorax originating in the perinatal period
Defination: Abnormal presence of air or other gas in the pleural cavity, usually secondary to tracking of free air from pulmonary interstitial emphysema, or rupture of subpleural blebs.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Pneumomediastinum originating in the perinatal period
Defination: Presence of air in the mediastinum usually from tracking of free air from ruptured alveolar ducts along the perivascular sheaths of pulmonary blood vessels, or rupture of subpleural bleb

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Pneumopericardium originating in the perinatal period
Defination: Presence of air in the pericardial cavity usually from tracking of free air from ruptured alveolar ducts along the perivascular sheaths of pulmonary blood vessels, or rupture of subpleural bleb

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Pneumoperitoneum, originating in the perinatal period, due to primary pulmonary air leak syndromes

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - Pulmonary haemorrhage originating in the perinatal period
Defination: A condition characterised by bleeding from the lung which begins during the period of time around childbirth, especially the five months before and one month after birth.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - Chronic respiratory disease originating in the perinatal period
Defination: A group of conditions associated with the respiratory system which begin during the period of time around childbirth, especially the five months before and one month after birth, and which lasts for at least 3 months.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - - Bronchopulmonary dysplasia originating in the perinatal period
Defination: Chronic lung disease requiring treatment with oxygen for at least 28 days and with a spectrum of severity from mild to severe, that predominantly affects premature infants.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Any condition characterised by suspension of external breathing in a newborn (premature or term) which is not classified elsewhere

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Acute or chronic respiratory failure in a newborn. Neonates in acute respiratory failure require respiratory support.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Collapsed lobe or lobes of the lung that is present at birth and is due to narrowing of the airway, kinking of the airway, compression from a mass in the airway or other congenital abnormality.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Category: - - Airway obstruction in the neonate due to airway abnormality

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Tracheomalacia is a condition characterised by flaccidity of the tracheal support cartilage causing weakness of the tracheobronchial tree and tracheal collapse.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Respiratory disorders specific to the perinatal or neonatal period

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Cardiovascular disorders present in the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: A condition characterised as a congenital disorder in the heart wherein a neonate's ductus arteriosus abnormally remains open longer than the first few days after birth.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Cardiovascular disorders present in the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Hypertension is defined by a systolic blood pressure in a neonate which is >95th percentile for age and sex on 3 separate occasions

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Cardiovascular disorders present in the perinatal or neonatal period
Defination: Mean Arterial Blood Pressure below gestational age in weeks (corresponds with 10th centile for birth weight and postnatal age1) or below 30mmHg as hypotension

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Transitory endocrine or metabolic disorders specific to fetus or newborn
Category: - - Transitory disorders of carbohydrate metabolism specific to fetus or newborn
Defination: A group of paediatric conditions in which there is a temporary disorder in a newborn or infant associated with abnormal chemical reactions in the body disrupting the process of getting or making energy from consumed carbohydrates.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Transitory endocrine or metabolic disorders specific to fetus or newborn

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Transitory endocrine or metabolic disorders specific to fetus or newborn

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Transitory endocrine or metabolic disorders specific to fetus or newborn
Category: - - Transitory neonatal disorders of calcium or magnesium metabolism
Defination: A group of paediatric conditions in which there is a temporary disorder in a newborn associated with abnormal chemical reactions in the body disrupting the normal processes of enzyme catalyzed reactions to utilize calcium and magnesium for other body functions.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Transitory endocrine or metabolic disorders specific to fetus or newborn
Defination: Defined as serum magnesium levels less than 0.66 mmol/L (1.6 mg/L) in neonates. Symptoms usually do not develop until serum Mg levels falls below 0.49 mmol/L (1.2 mg/L).This is usually transient but can cause symptoms similar to those of hypocalcaemia.

Chapter Name: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period
BlockL1: - Transitory endocrine or metabolic disorders specific to fetus or newborn
Defination: Hypocalcaemia is a common metabolic problem in newborns. In the neonate, hypocalcaemia is defined by birth weight (BW) categories. In infants with BW greater than 1500 g, hypocalcaemia is defined as a total serum Calcium (Ca) concentration less than 8 mg/dL (2 mmol/L) or an ionized fraction of less than 4.4 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L). In very low birth weight premature infants (BW<1500g), hypocalcaemia is defined as a total serum Ca concentration less than 7 mg/dL (1.75 mmol/L) or an ionized fraction of less than 4 mg/dL (1 mmol/L). Etiologies of early hypocalcaemia (occurs in the first two to three days after birth) include prematurity, maternal diabetes, birth asphyxia, and intrauterine growth.
